title: Fuel Tank - Removal

body.body: Warning - General - Stabilise Motorcycle - including DO NOT support on non integral parts
Make sure the motorcycle is stabilised and adequately supported.
Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
A fire, causing personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.
Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
Before disconnecting any fuel lines, make sure the engine and exhaust system has cooled down.
A fire, causing personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.

Never drain fuel from the tank using non-approved, non-professional standard fuel handling equipment. A fire causing destruction of property and injury to persons may result from use of non-approved fuel handling equipment.
Using proprietary professional automotive workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, drain the fuel from the fuel tank.
Remove the omega clip from the main harness conduit.
Remove the front fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (right hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (right hand shown)
Remove the front fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (left hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Remove the fixings from the front bracket.
With the aid of an assistant, tilt the fuel tank rearward to gain access to the underside.
Remove the 20Amp fuse PS#5 from the fuse box.
If the fuel rail is dismantled without first reducing pressure, fuel may escape causing clothing and components to be coated with fuel.
This would represent a serious fire hazard which could lead to burn injuries and damage to property.

Because fuel stored in the fuel rail will be at high pressure, it is essential that the fuel pressure is reduced before any dismantling of the fuel rail takes place. To reduce pressure, briefly crank the engine with the fuel pump fuse removed.
When disconnected, the fuel tank is self-sealing but a small amount of fuel may dribble from the hose.
To protect the components under the fuel tank, place suitable material over the components to absorb the small amount of fuel that may come from the fuel tank and its fuel lines.
Start the engine and run until it stalls to drain fuel from the fuel rail.
With the aid of an assistant raise the fuel tank.
Before disconnection, note that the evaporative hose has a 7 mm internal diameter and the fuel tank drain hose a 5 mm internal diameter.
Make sure the hoses are returned to the same locations when fitting the fuel tank.
Noting the position of the rubber bands.
Disconnect the fuel pump electrical connection (brown).
Disconnect the fuel level sender electrical connection (black).
Disconnect the keyless fuel cap electrical connection (white).
Disconnect the fuel tank drain hose
Fuel tank drain hose (internal diameter 5 mm)
Do not pull on the fuel hose to disconnect the connector from the fuel rail.
Pulling on the fuel hose may damage the fuel hose connector.
Disconnect from the fuel line by lifting up the fuel hose connector.
To release the double check clip, ease the latch away from the connector until the release buttons are exposed.
Press in the release buttons (one either side of the fuel hose connector) to release the locking device.
Without pulling on the fuel hose, push the fuel hose connector towards the fuel tank to disconnect it from the spigot.
Remove the rear bracket rear fixing fixings securing the rear fuel tank bracket to the frame.
Rear bracket front fixing (left hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Position the fuel tank bracket away from the stop screws.

Do not support the motorcycle on any ancillary component, the exhaust system or any other non structural parts of the motorcycle frame.
A correctly supported motorcycle will help prevent it from falling.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in serious injury or death.
Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.

Observe the warning advice given in the General Information section on the safe handling of fuel and fuel containers.
Before disconnecting any fuel lines, make sure the engine and exhaust system has cooled down.
A fire, causing personal injury and damage to property could result from spilled fuel or fuel not handled or stored correctly.

Never drain fuel from the tank using non-approved, non-professional standard fuel handling equipment. A fire causing destruction of property and injury to persons may result from use of non-approved fuel handling equipment.
Perform the following operations:
Seats - Removal
Battery - Removal
Using proprietary professional automotive workshop equipment approved for fuel handling, drain the fuel from the fuel tank.
Remove the omega clip from the main harness conduit.
Remove the front fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the right hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (right hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (right hand shown)
Omega clip
Battery negative lead
Remove the front fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Loosen but do not fully remove the rear fixing from the left hand side of the rear bracket.
Rear bracket front fixing (left hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Stop screw (left hand shown)
Rear bracket
Remove the fixings from the front bracket.
Fuel tank
Fixings
With the aid of an assistant, tilt the fuel tank rearward to gain access to the underside.
Remove the 20Amp fuse PS#5 from the fuse box.
Front fuse box location
Fuel pump fuse location
Fuse box
If the fuel rail is dismantled without first reducing pressure, fuel may escape causing clothing and components to be coated with fuel.
This would represent a serious fire hazard which could lead to burn injuries and damage to property.

Because fuel stored in the fuel rail will be at high pressure, it is essential that the fuel pressure is reduced before any dismantling of the fuel rail takes place. To reduce pressure, briefly crank the engine with the fuel pump fuse removed.
When disconnected, the fuel tank is self-sealing but a small amount of fuel may dribble from the hose.
To protect the components under the fuel tank, place suitable material over the components to absorb the small amount of fuel that may come from the fuel tank and its fuel lines.
Temporarily refit the battery, see
Battery - Installation
Start the engine and run until it stalls to drain fuel from the fuel rail.
Remove the battery, see
Battery - Removal
With the aid of an assistant raise the fuel tank.
Before disconnection, note that the evaporative hose has a 7 mm internal diameter and the fuel tank drain hose a 5 mm internal diameter.
Make sure the hoses are returned to the same locations when fitting the fuel tank.
Noting the position of the rubber bands.
Disconnect the fuel pump electrical connection (brown).
Disconnect the fuel level sender electrical connection (black).
Disconnect the keyless fuel cap electrical connection (white).
Disconnect the evaporative hose.
Disconnect the fuel tank drain hose
Fuel connector
Fuel pump electrical connection (brown
Fuel level sender electrical connection (black)
Rubber straps
Fuse box
Evaporative hose (internal diameter 7 mm)
Fuel tank drain hose (internal diameter 5 mm)
Keyless fuel cap electrical connection (white)
Do not pull on the fuel hose to disconnect the connector from the fuel rail.
Pulling on the fuel hose may damage the fuel hose connector.
Disconnect from the fuel line by lifting up the fuel hose connector.
To release the double check clip, ease the latch away from the connector until the release buttons are exposed.
Press in the release buttons (one either side of the fuel hose connector) to release the locking device.
Without pulling on the fuel hose, push the fuel hose connector towards the fuel tank to disconnect it from the spigot.
Locked position
Unlocked position
Remove the rear bracket rear fixing fixings securing the rear fuel tank bracket to the frame.
Rear bracket front fixing (left hand shown)
Rear bracket rear fixing (left hand shown)
Stop screw (left hand shown)
Rear bracket
Position the fuel tank bracket away from the stop screws.
Remove the fuel tank.
